Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2013 02:48AM lotusblossom wrote: Hi MGordon, When I started on Navelbine, it was very slow to work, and I even had slight progression in my axilla lymph node. It was after about 9 months on it that all of a sudden the tumors started to melt away.  I have been on Navelbine for 2 years now and the CT scan shows: almost complete resolution of metastases. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Navelbine- how long does it take to work? mgordon mgordon

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2012 05:11AM lotusblossom wrote: TN here since June 2009.  I was working full time until yesterday.  I had a management position where I had to miss quite a bit of business travel because of my chemo schedule.  The company pulled me from my position and gave me 'special projects', the ultimate kiss of death....  They told me that as a business they could not have a manager who was 'taking so long to get into remission'!!!!  So, I hung in for the special projects position for the past six months.  Finally, a couple of weeks ago, I was told that they were suprised I was still there and hadn't quit yet.  Then I was told to either choose permanent disability or termination with a package.  They also told me that they knew it was all illegal, but had to do it anyways.  I talked with my onc about suing and he told me that if going onto disability was not going to hurt me financially, then do it.  No use putting myself through needless stress, so I did it yesterday.  I guess my point is, depending on your job, even if you think you can still perform and have something to give your employer, make sure they are on board with that.  My employer likes to squeeze employees like lemons, so it was no longer a good fit for me. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Others who are triple negative - how long on chemo? TNIV menan

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2013 03:49PM lotusblossom wrote: It's ironic, isn't it?  I was the HR Director for a Research Institute, and a lawyer by training.  I had protected other employees who had cancer, but had nobody to protect me... We have enough on our plates without having to fight for our rights as well.
Posts.Title: Anyone else still working and facing discrimination at work? BouncingBetties BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2013 06:23AM lotusblossom wrote: Bouncing, I see that you are in Alberta.  I am in Québec.  Last year, I was removed from my management position and given "special projects", which is basicslly the career kiss-of-death.  I stuck it out for a few months.  Then I was told that since I insisted on hanging around, my position was being eliminated.  I went to a labour lawyer, who confirmed that, according to the Canadian Human Rights Act, my employer had the obligation to accomodate me.  He also told me though that they could also drag the whole thing on in the court system for a long time.  My oncologist said it wasn't worth the stress.  So, I negociated a package and went onto LTD.  Now I am trying to educate the public here in Québec about the discrimination that stage IV patients face in the workplace.  Two weeks ago, I did a piece with Global News and this week I did a taping for a French medical show that is doing a piece on the subject.  Long story short, prepare yourself.  Employers look at us like a liability. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Anyone else still working and facing discrimination at work? BouncingBetties BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2014 07:00PM - edited Jun 17, 2014 07:01PM by lotusblossom Hi Sherbab, I was on Navelbine for 30 months. It was a very easy chemo although I did have hair thinning. I would also get joint and muscle aches about 2 days after infusion. It would last about 24 hours. Navelbine was my fifth line of chemo. Like you, I am TN. It eventually got me to NED.  Good luck! Lotusblossom
Posts.Title: Starting Navelbine on Monday - Any advice sherbab RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 01:03PM lotusblossom wrote: Hi SPAMgirl, I have 3 children.  My 2 oldest were 17 and 20 when I was diagnosed (stage IV from the start) and my youngest was 5.  She is now 9 years old.  While she is not going through the same thing as your son, we do know that my situation is affecting her in school.  She has more difficulty visualising and using her imagination than the other children have.  She tries to be very mature and controlled, which is not what being a nine year old should be about. In class they talked about getting the HPV vaccine and ovarian cancer.  She told the other children in class that her mom had cancer and would never be cured.  The teacher told me it was quite an emotional conversation and that many of the children had tears in their eyes as she told our story... You think that they are too young to really understand, but they understand much more than we think they do and sometimes their frustration comes out in ways that we might not easily be able to control. Like you, I also thought I was too lax and spoke to the teacher about it.  She told me that being lax was probably the wisest thing I can do.  These kids have enough on their plates. That being said, I try to not let her get away with too much and always ask the school to let me know when they think something is up that we might be missing at home.
Posts.Title: Children misbehaving SPAMgirl texasrose361

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2012 04:46PM lotusblossom wrote: Hi Michelle, I have been triple negative stage IV since June 2009. I am sorry that you are joining us. There are many TN on this board who have been around for years. Remember that TN responds very well to chemo, particularly taxanes, so try to calm you fears. Taxol kept me stable and feeling good for 15 months!

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 05:51AM lotusblossom wrote: I am so sorry to hear about your sister in law, but you have found a good place for information and support. I was also diagnosed at stage IV from the get go. That was 3.5 years ago and I am still doing very well. I am Canadian and was concerned that I might not have access to the best services. I was lucky enough to have private insurance that allowed me to get a second opinion through Best Doctors. So I was able to get a second opinion at Dana Farber, where they told me that my Canadian hospital was doing the best for me. My oncologist is American and I have told him that I will go wherever I need to for treatment. He says there is no need since Canada has access to the best treatments available. I have heard that British Columbia has world class treatments and lots of research going on, so I think you are at the right place. When I asked my oncologist about clinical trials, he told me it is something to use after standard treatment has been tried. I trust him immensely, he has an excellent reputation and is a professor/researcher at McGill University. My recommendation is that,once the shock of the diagnosis has lessened, take the time to have a talk with the oncologist so that he can explain what can be offered to your sister in law in BC and so that you can make informed decisions. I know that, from what I have seen on these boards, we seem to have easier access in Canada than many of the other countries.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Stage IV trial2me trial2me

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2015 10:02AM lotusblossom wrote: Hi OMD, I was on Navelbine for 2.5 years. During the first few months on it, I was stable. After about 6 months, I had slight progression but my onc kept me on it because it was my 5th line of treatment and options were running out. I think I had 2 scans that showed slight progression. At about the 2 year mark, I began to have significant improvement. At the 2.5 year mark, I was NED and have been that way for the past 15 months. So, yes, things can improve with no change in treatment! At first, I thought my onc was crazy to keep me on it when I was showing slight progression, but his patience ended up being the right decision. Lotusblossom
Posts.Title: Can things improve with no change in treatment? Ohmydarlin Healedforever

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 01:21PM lotusblossom wrote: Chicagogirl, I always take the cue from my onc. I have aggressive TN and was only given a week here and there. But I know that I tolerated treatment better than most people. The first time my onc gave me a week off, it was after about 8 months of treatment. So, I would ask your onc's opinion. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Long Term Survivors with No Surgery? MusicLover MusicLover

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 06:47AM lotusblossom wrote: Hi Carla, I am also triple negative, diagnosed at stage IV fom the get go in 2009.   I went onto STD for 4 months while I got my head around the diagnosis.  At the time, I was on Gezar/Xeloda. After 4 months of treatment, I was really anxious to get back to work, so I decided to go back full-time.  Then the hand and foot syndrom hit me.  I ended up having to go to work in slippers and gloves. since the skin was just falling off of my feet so badly.  It would take me forever to walk to the ladies' room or the cafeteria.  But since my mind was all there and I have a desk job, I continued to go. It was only after I was taken off this combo that employees started to tell me how difficult it was for them to see me in that state.  I realize now that working during that period did me more harm than good, and negatively affected the employees, who really felt sorry seeing me come into the office. Then, I switched to Taxol.  After I lost all my hair, the president could no longer look me in the face.  Even though I felt great and was stable, the office took the fact that I was bald as a bad sign.   Just this year, I was removed from my management position and given 'special projects'.  I was told that senior management does not believe that I will live long enough to be promotable into a new role, no matter how hard i may work .  They tell me this regardless of the fact that I have been stable for 3 years now and am finally having regression. So, in my case, it is the company pushing me out.  Senior management feels uncomfortable having me around.  I feel like I have become a persona non grata.  I made the mistake of giving time and energy to an employer who is afraid of death and afraid of cancer.  The employees support me 100%, but not management, BTW, a company who knows I have cancer has just offered me a job. So, I guess my point is: know your employer, make sure that they will support you, regardless of the decision you make. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Keep working or not? Questions from a newbie Carla9112 lisalock

It eventually gets easier.  Know that you are not alone and that there are many options available to you!

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2014 04:58PM lotusblossom wrote: Curleygirley, I was also stage IV at diagnosis, I know what a shock it is.  You will learn to find a new "normal" and start to navigate through all of the emotions and challenges that a stage IV diagnosis brings. You have found the right place by coming here. These women can provide info, insight, motivation or a shoulder to cry on, whatever you need. BTW, I was 45 at diagnosis. That was almost 5 years ago. Today I found out I am disease-free.  There are so many new protocols, drugs, etc. that a stage IV diagnosis no longer means what it meant years ago. I see you are from Ontario. Are you in Toronto? I have heard that the Princess Margaret is excellent.  It is the model that my hospital in Montreal follows. Hugs from Lotusblossom
Posts.Title: From a lump to stage 4 within a month! What now ....... curleygirly Mompsych

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 11:37AM lotusblossom wrote: I have been on Navelibine for almost 9 months now, 2 weeks on 1 week off.  My dosage is 57 (I weight 164 lbs).  My first scan came back as stable, my second showed regression in the lungs and spleen and my third scan showed stable lungs, more regression in spleen and NED in mediastinal and hilar nodes.  I am very happy with this and this is the best response I have had in three years.  SEs are not bad, I still work and am training for a 200 km bike ride to raise funds for our hospital's cancer center.  Also, hair is actually growing back - not pretty, but at least it's there!
Posts.Title: For those on navelbine LuAnnH onedayatatime

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2015 01:47PM lotusblossom wrote: Hi all, I was diagnosed with mets from the get-go in June 2009. At the time of diagnosis, my mets were so extensive that the PET scan report was 3 pages long. My onc told me I looked like I had been in a radioactive accident. Mets included axilla nodes, neck nodes, hilar and mediastinal nodes, lungs, biliary tract, spleen, pericardial sac, pancreas,spine, muscles and soft tissue. I started treatment with Xeloda/Gemzar for 8 months. Initially there was some response but then eventually progression. I was switched to Caelyx(Doxil?) which failed. I then was switched to Taxol for 16 months. Again, initial response to progression. Then I was switched to Navelbine as a last resort. Navelbine kept me stable for 20 months. Then, quite suddenly, I began to show rapid response which brought me to NED. That was in February 2013. I have been without treatment since. Throughout my treatment, I never took more than a couple of weeks of chemo holiday and was diligent in all health matters. I exercised regularly and continued to work until the day my employer forced me onto disability (that's a whole other story). It has been almost 6 years since my stage 4 diagnosis. I am doing well. Here is a video that I did with the Canadian Breast Cancer Network called "Living Legacy". We are 3 participants in the video, 2 of us are stage 4 TN. I am the red head with the Chinese name, which in English means lotus blossom. I hope the link works..... http://www.cbcn.ca/index.php?pageaction=content.pa...
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2015 09:37PM lotusblossom wrote: Hi Smiley47, I was ln Taxol for about 16 months before progression. My onc then switched me to Navelbine, which I tolerated well for 2.5 years. It brought ne to NED. I have been NED and out of treatment for the past 12 months. Lotusblossom
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 07:32PM lotusblossom wrote: I'm here too. Diagnosed at stage IV from the get-go in June 2009 with mets to bone, lungs, biliary tract,spleen and nodes from neck to pelvis.  I was on Gemzar/Xeloda for 8 months, then Caelyx for 4.  Taxol kept me stable for 12 months and navelbine has now kept me stable for 16 months.  At this point. I only have small mets to lungs (largest is 6mm).  I will be turnng 49 later this month and am excitedly looking to celebrating the big 50!!
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 02:37PM lotusblossom wrote: 11tybillion, I have been on Navelbine since August 2010.  It has been a very easy chemo and has significantly reduced my mets. I actually feel like life is 'normal' on Navelbine.  Also, my nurses tell me that when it works, it works for a long time. I met one woman wo has been stable on it for 5 years! My youngest was 5 when I got my diagnosis in 2009.  I was stunned, since I felt fine.  Since diagnosis, I have continued to be very busy: work, exercise and trying to be the best Mom possible.  My onc calls me the Eveready bunny!  He thinks that my activity is what makes the difference for me.  Since diagnosis, I have had mostly stability or regression (knock on wood).  My onc keeps on telling me to say busy and not stop. So, I think you are right when you say that your exercise and eating well has made a difference. Don't stop!!! We need to put all our chances on our side!! Good luck with the Navelbine!  I hope it kicks those mets to the curb!
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 06:50AM lotusblossom wrote: Surfdreams, I initially started with mets in my lungs, spleen , biliary tract, bones and lymph nodes. I was put on Gemzar/Xeloda and had some regression then stability. When I began to progress my MO put me on Caelyx, where I progressed again. Then he put me on Taxol, where I was stable for over a year, and then progressed. Finally, he put me on Navelbine. At first stable for 6 months, then HUGE regression, stable, then regression again! I have been on Navelbine for almost 2 years and now have only tiny lung nodules! It took a long time for me to get to this place where I finally feel like there is hope, but there it is!
